newsitem.title: USA: NY Power Authority's 780 MW Fitzpatrick trips off.
newsitem.headline: NY Power Authority's 780 MW Fitzpatrick trips off.

text.p: The New York Power Authority's Fitzpatrick 1 nuclear power station automatically tripped off line following an error by plant personnel, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC) said Tuesday.
The 780 megawatt (MW) plant, in Scriba, N.Y., was running at 100 percent of its rated capacity just before the outage.
The unit's reactor is being kept in hot standby mode, the NRC said.
The Power Authority told the NRC that a technician apparently caused an electrical short, which in turn opened the generator output breakers and automatically tripped the rector.
The outage took place about 1340 EDT Monday.
Power Authority officials were not immediately available for comment on the outage or its likely duration.
The New York Power Authority is a state-owned agency providing wholesale power throughout New York state.
It also operates the 965 MW Indian Point 3 nuclear power plant in Indian Point, N.Y., along the Hudson River. That unit was still operating at full capacity as of early Tuesday, the NRC said.
